Posts.Title: Question about Biopsy jushavinfun jushavinfun

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2013 05:05AM learningtoletgo wrote: You are a very wise woman! I, too, have decided to stand my ground and ask to have things done my way. I have a "suspicious" benign appearing solid "lobular" nodule with "circumscribed" borders for which a "stereotactic core needle biopsy was ordered. I said "no". I wanted them to do a "excisional" biopsy instead. That way, if indeed I do have cancer, they aren't cutting into it, but around it. I have read too much about biopsy needles "seeding" cancer cells when they are pulled back out. I told my doctor and insurance company that I wanted the thing out of my body even if it was benign and they listened!
Posts.Title: Wont Play the Wait and Watch sunnyinutah Jenny2578

Posts.Content: May 5, 2013 04:41AM learningtoletgo wrote: Melissa, thank you. I guess there is so much controversy out there on the subject that each person just has to do what they feel is right for them. I'll post my results once I get them.
Posts.Title: Do FNA and Stereotactic Core Needle Biopsy cause "seeding"of BC? learningtoletgo letsgogolf

Posts.Content: May 6, 2013 06:30AM learningtoletgo wrote: Beesie, I appreciate that you took the time to provide this info because like I said, I have already had a needle biopsy and am simply concerned that it could make things worse down the road. For all I know, my lump may turn out benign (please God!). Just looking and learning as much as my brain will allow! I don't want to make decisions based on fear but rather be an informed patient. When I found out that 80% of all biopsies are benign to begin with, you have to wonder why all these biopsies in the first place? When I researched that and found out that it is the referring Radiologist who profits directly (they keep the fee for needle biopsies), you have to wonder if the "suspicious" lump was ever suspicious at all. As I said, women with a lump will do whatever recommended out of fear and doctors of all specialties know this. Profit could well be behind current standard treatments and diagnostic methods. It wouldn't be the first time and probably won't be the last.

Posts.Content: May 5, 2013 02:49AM learningtoletgo wrote: Stephluisa, I am so sorry to hear that this is happening to you, again. Sometimes, I wonder if the biopsy procedure itself is causing all these reoccurances of BC in survivors. Supposedly, these needle and incisional biopsies are safe, but I have my doubts. It makes sense to me that they would want to use a less invasive procedure of getting a sample of tissue for diagnostic purposes. Anyway, I wish you the best.
Posts.Title: Having pain in diagnosed breast and fever after five years! stephluisa stephluisa

Posts.Content: May 6, 2013 01:02AM - edited May 6, 2013 01:07AM by learningtoletgo Susie, thank you for sharing that info. After reading the article that the moderators of this site provided, it is interesting that the biopsy process for testicular cancer is to NEVER PERFORM A NEEDLE BIOPSY OR ANYTHING OTHER THAN A COMPLETE REMOVAL OF THE TUMOR. It is very interesting. Upon further research, there was a study done in 2004 called the Hansen Study that showed that there was a 50% chance for micrometastases to the Sentinal Node after Fine Needle Biopsy. Here is the link: breastcancerchoices.org

Posts.Title: Do FNA and Stereotactic Core Needle Biopsy cause "seeding"of BC? learningtoletgo letsgogolf

Posts.Content: May 6, 2013 04:50AM - edited May 6, 2013 08:21AM by learningtoletgo MelissaDallas, the website I found was just one of many that showed there is data out there disputing the safety of needle biopsies. I am just doing research, that's all. I know nothing. Just because a particular study says one thing and another study disputes that doesn't prove either are right. As for assurances that something is safe, remember when gynocologists everywhere assured us women that HRT was safe to use for menopause and later those same doctors were proven wrong after the data came back showing it wasn't (Womens Health Initiative)? I pray you are right.

Posts.Title: Do FNA and Stereotactic Core Needle Biopsy cause "seeding"of BC? learningtoletgo letsgogolf

Posts.Content: May 5, 2013 03:34AM learningtoletgo wrote: Stephluisa, no...I am still waiting for a diagnosis after having the needle biopsy procedure myself. It didn't really bother me all that much, though. I guess it is different for everyone. Well, while I have been waiting for results, I have been doing a lot of research and there is data out there saying that these needle biopsies can, themselves, cause the cancer to spread. Some having suggested that it causes what would have been a lower staged cancer to become a higher staged cancer later. I almost wish now that I had requested that they remove my lump "intact" before sending a sample off to the pathologist for diagnosis. I wonder how many BC survivors have had a reoccurance due to the biopsy procedure...oh, well, too late for me since it was already done. Now I have to wait for results.
